column2: Two basic principles: how are AC sources handled (paralleling and connecting sources)?
column3: No paralleling of AC sources. Connecting a source to a transfer bus automatically disconnects an existing source.

column2: What are the three main divisions of the B737 electrical power system?
column3: AC power system; DC power system; standby power system.

column2: Each AC power system consists of what buses?
column3: Transfer bus; main bus; two galley buses; ground service bus.

column2: Which transfer bus supplies the AC standby bus (normal)?
column3: Transfer bus 1 supplies the AC standby bus.

column2: If the AC source powering a transfer bus fails or is disconnected, how can that transfer bus be powered?
column3: It can be powered by any available source through the tie bus via the bus tie breakers (BTBs).

column2: On the ground with both GEN control switches OFF (or both engines shut down), what does selecting GRD PWR ON do?
column3: Connects external power to both transfer buses (if power quality is correct).

column2: On the ground, selecting either APU GEN switch ON does what to the transfer buses?
column3: Connects APU power to both transfer buses.

column2: Can one transfer bus be powered by external power while the other is powered by the APU?
column3: No. It is not possible to power one transfer bus with external power and the other with APU power.

column2: GEN switch (ENG) — what does OFF do?
column3: Disconnects the IDG from the related AC transfer bus by opening the generator circuit breaker.

column2: GEN switch (ENG) — what does ON do (momentary)?
column3: Connects the IDG to the related AC transfer bus by disconnecting the previous power source and closing the generator circuit breaker.

column2: In flight, with one engine generator no longer supplying power and BUS TRANSFER in AUTO, what happens to the transfer buses?
column3: BTBs automatically close so the remaining generator can supply both transfer buses through the tie bus/BTBs.

column2: If the airplane takes off with the APU powering both transfer buses and the APU is shut down or fails, what happens?
column3: Engine generators are automatically connected to their related transfer buses. This occurs only once in flight and only in that circumstance.

column2: BUS TRANSFER switch — AUTO (guarded): what does it allow for AC and DC?
column3: AC: BTBs operate automatically to maintain power to AC transfer buses from any operating generator or external power. DC: DC cross tie relay automatically provides normal or isolated operation as required.

column2: BUS TRANSFER switch — OFF: what does it do (AC + DC + TR3 input)?
column3: AC: isolates AC transfer bus 1 from AC transfer bus 2 (if one IDG is supplying both). DC: DC cross tie relay opens to isolate DC bus 1 from DC bus 2. Also inhibits TR3 input from connecting to AC transfer bus 1.

column2: If BUS TRANSFER is in AUTO and the source powering a transfer bus is disconnected or fails, what occurs?
column3: The source powering the opposite transfer bus automatically picks up the unpowered transfer bus through the BTBs.

column2: Single generator operation: what loads are shed first/next/then (automatic load shedding)?
column3: Sheds incrementally by load sensing: (1) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 2; (2) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 1; (3) IFE buses (if overload persists).

column2: When source capacity returns to two-generator operation, what restores automatically and what requires CAB/UTIL reset?
column3: IFE/PASS buses restore automatically. Galley and main bus power require CAB/UTIL switch reset (OFF then ON) to restore.

column2: APU-only electrical power in flight: what is shed automatically (and what else if overload persists)?
column3: All galley buses and main buses are automatically shed. If load still exceeds limits, both IFE buses are also automatically shed.

column2: APU on the ground with overload sensed: what does the APU shed, and how can you attempt restoration?
column3: Sheds galley buses and main buses until load is within limits. Restoration can be attempted by moving CAB/UTIL switch OFF then back ON.

column2: DC power system: what supplies 28V DC power under normal conditions?
column3: Three transformer-rectifier (TR) units energized from the AC transfer buses supply 28V DC.

column2: TR units convert what to what?
column3: Convert 115V AC to 28V DC.

column2: Which AC transfer bus powers TR1 and TR2?
column3: TR1 receives AC power from transfer bus 1. TR2 receives AC power from transfer bus 2.

column2: TR3 normally receives AC power from which transfer bus, and what is its backup source (when BUS TRANSFER is AUTO)?
column3: Normally from transfer bus 2, with backup AC power from transfer bus 1.

column2: How many TRs are required to supply the total connected load?
column3: Any two TRs are capable of supplying the total connected load.

column2: Under normal conditions, how are DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby bus connected, and what does that allow?
column3: They are connected via the cross bus tie relay; TR1 and TR2 each power DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby bus.
column5: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (DC buses / cross bus tie relay)

column2: Under normal conditions, what does TR3 power and what is its role?
column3: TR3 powers the battery bus and serves as a backup power source for TR1 and TR2.

column2: Cross bus tie relay: under what conditions does it automatically open (isolate DC bus 1 from DC bus 2)?
column3: At glideslope capture during a flight director or autopilot ILS approach; and when the BUS TRANSFER switch is positioned to OFF.
column5: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (Cross bus tie relay) + §6.10.4 (BUS TRANSFER OFF)

column2: TR UNIT light: when does it illuminate in flight vs on the ground?
column3: In flight: illuminates if TR1, or TR2 and TR3 has failed. On the ground: any TR fault causes the light to illuminate.

column2: ELEC light: what does it indicate on the ground, and what is its in-flight logic?
column3: On the ground: indicates a fault exists in the DC power system or standby power system. In flight: ELEC light is inhibited.

column2: Battery: what type/nominal voltage and where is it located?
column3: Single 24V nickel-cadmium battery located in the electronics compartment.

column2: Battery capacity: a fully charged battery provides standby power for at least how long?
column3: Minimum of 30 minutes.

column2: Battery voltage range (volts)?
column3: 22–30 volts.

column2: After loss of both generators, which DC buses are powered from the battery?
column3: Battery bus; DC standby bus; hot battery bus; switched hot battery bus.

column2: Switched hot battery bus: when is it powered?
column3: Powered whenever the battery switch is ON.

column2: Hot battery bus: how is it connected to the battery?
column3: Always connected to the battery; there is no switch in this circuit.

column2: Standby power system: what does it provide, and when?
column3: Provides 115V AC and 24V DC power to essential systems in the event of loss of all engine or APU-driven AC power.

column2: Standby power system consists of what components/buses?
column3: Static inverter; AC standby bus; DC standby bus; battery bus; hot battery bus; switched hot battery bus; main battery.

column2: Normal standby power sources (AUTO, battery switch ON): what powers AC standby bus, DC standby bus, battery bus, hot & switched hot battery buses?
column3: AC standby bus: AC transfer bus 1. DC standby bus: TR1/TR2/TR3. Battery bus: TR3. Hot & switched hot battery buses: battery/battery charger.

column2: With standby power switch in AUTO, loss of all engine/APU electrical power causes what standby power configuration?
column3: Battery powers standby loads (air or ground). AC standby bus powered from battery via static inverter. DC standby bus, battery bus, hot & switched hot battery buses powered directly from battery.

column2: Standby power switch — AUTO: when does automatic switching from normal to alternate occur?
column3: If power from either AC transfer bus 1 or DC bus 1 is lost.

column2: Standby power switch — BAT: what does it do (and what happens if BAT switch is OFF)?
column3: Overrides automatic switching and places AC standby bus, DC standby bus, and battery bus on battery power. Battery switch may be ON or OFF; if battery switch is OFF, the switched hot battery bus is not powered.

column2: Standby power switch — OFF: what happens?
column3: De-energizes AC standby bus and DC standby bus and illuminates the STANDBY PWR OFF light.

column2: Static inverter: what does it do, and what controls its power supply?
column3: Converts 24V DC from the battery to 115V AC to supply the AC standby bus during loss of normal electrical power. Inverter power supply is controlled by the standby power switch and the battery switch.

column2: GROUND SERVICE switch: what does it do when ON (illuminated)?
column3: Connects external power to the ground service buses (manual control) to service the airplane without activating AC transfer buses.

column2: AC/DC metering panel: what do the AC ammeter/voltmeter/frequency meter indicate?
column3: Indicate amperage/voltage/frequency of the source selected by the AC meters selector.

column2: AC/DC metering panel: what do the DC ammeter/voltmeter indicate?
column3: Indicate amperage/voltage of the source selected by the DC meters selector.

column2: GRD POWER AVAILABLE light: what does it mean?
column3: Ground power is connected and meets airplane power quality standards.

column2: GRD PWR switch: what does OFF do?
column3: Disconnects ground power from the AC transfer buses.

column2: GRD PWR switch: when moved to ON (with ground power available), what happens?
column3: Removes previously connected power from AC transfer buses, then connects ground power to the AC transfer buses (if power quality is correct).

column2: TRANSFER BUS OFF light: what does it indicate?
column3: Related transfer bus is not powered.

column2: SOURCE OFF light: what does it indicate, and what if the opposite transfer bus has a source selected?
column3: No source has been manually selected to power the related transfer bus, or the manually selected source has been disconnected. If a source has been selected to power the opposite transfer bus, both transfer buses are powered.

column2: GEN OFF BUS light: what does it indicate?
column3: IDG is not supplying power to the related transfer bus.
